text: For I know him, that he will command his children and his household after him, and they shall keep the way of the LORD, to do justice and judgment; that the LORD may bring upon Abraham that which he hath spoken of him.
text_kjv: For I know him, that he will command his children and his household after him, and they shall keep the way of the LORD, to do justice and judgment; that the LORD may bring upon Abraham that which he hath spoken of him.
text_niv: For I have chosen him, so that he will direct his children and his household after him to keep the way of the Lord by doing what is right and just, so that the Lord will bring about for Abraham what he has promised him.”
text_esv: For I have chosen  him, that he may command his children and his household after him to keep the way of the LORD by doing righteousness and justice, so that the LORD may bring to Abraham what he has promised him.”
text_nlt: I have singled him out so that he will direct his sons and their families to keep the way of the LORD by doing what is right and just. Then I will do for Abraham all that I have promised.”
text_msg: Yes, I've settled on him as the one to train his children and future family to observe God's way of life, live kindly and generously and fairly, so that God can complete in Abraham what he promised him."
text_nasb: 'For I have chosen him, so that he may command his children and his household after him to keep the way of the LORD by doing righteousness and justice, so that the LORD may bring upon Abraham what He has spoken about him.'
context: Genesis 18 takes place within the broader narrative of God's covenant with Abraham. The setting is the plains of Mamre, near Hebron, a significant location associated with Abraham's life and faith. Three visitors appear to Abraham, initially presented as men but soon revealed to be God (or divine representatives) accompanied by two angels. Hospitality was paramount in ancient Near Eastern culture, and Abraham's eagerness to welcome and serve these strangers reflects his character and adherence to societal norms. The announcement of Sarah's impending motherhood, despite her advanced age, underscores the miraculous nature of God's promise and challenges conventional understanding of human capability. This divine intervention highlights God's sovereignty and power to fulfill His promises, regardless of apparent impossibilities. Sodom and Gomorrah's imminent destruction sets the stage for the pivotal intercession by Abraham, a demonstration of his righteousness and concern for justice. The verses surrounding Genesis 18:19 portray a society deeply steeped in corruption and wickedness. The concept of generational responsibility was central to ancient Hebrew society; the head of the household bore immense responsibility for the spiritual and moral well-being of their entire family and even their servants. This was not merely a suggestion but an expectation of leadership and instruction in the ways of God. The patriarchal structure of the time placed significant authority on the father's shoulders, making his role in guiding his children's moral compass vital for the family's stability and their standing within the community. Failing in this duty brought shame not only upon the individual but also on the entire household. Abraham's expected obedience contrasted sharply with the impending doom awaiting Sodom and Gomorrah, cities that flagrantly disregarded God's moral laws.
meaning: Genesis 18:19 provides profound insight into God's character and His expectations of those in covenant with Him. The verse reveals God's intimate knowledge of Abraham, stating, “For I know him.” This is not merely an intellectual awareness but a deep, relational understanding. This "knowing" implies divine approval and recognition of Abraham's inherent qualities. God anticipates that Abraham will “command his children and his household after him,” emphasizing Abraham's responsibility for the spiritual formation of his descendants. The word “command” underscores the authoritative role Abraham is expected to play, actively instructing and guiding his family in the ways of the Lord. This command is not merely a suggestion but a divine expectation. The phrase “they shall keep the way of the LORD” speaks to the importance of obedience and adherence to God's moral law. "Keeping the way" means living a life that aligns with God's principles and commandments. This is not simply outward compliance but an inward transformation that shapes their thoughts, words, and actions. The purpose of this obedience is “to do justice and judgment.” This phrase refers to acting fairly and righteously in all aspects of life, upholding God's standard of moral excellence. It encompasses both interpersonal relationships and societal interactions. The ultimate goal is “that the LORD may bring upon Abraham that which he hath spoken of him.” This emphasizes the cause-and-effect relationship between obedience and the fulfillment of God's promises. God's blessings are contingent upon Abraham's faithfulness and his commitment to raising his children in the ways of righteousness. This verse reinforces the idea that covenant faithfulness is not merely an individual pursuit but also a generational responsibility, emphasizing the legacy of faith.
application: Genesis 18:19 serves as a powerful call to action for contemporary believers, particularly parents and those in positions of leadership. It compels us to examine our own commitment to spiritual formation within our families and communities. Firstly, the verse highlights the importance of intentional discipleship. Parents are called to actively teach their children about God's Word and His ways. This is not merely about attending church on Sundays but about integrating biblical principles into daily life. It means having open conversations about faith, modeling godly behavior, and creating opportunities for spiritual growth. Secondly, the emphasis on “justice and judgment” challenges us to live lives of integrity and righteousness in all our dealings. This includes treating others fairly, advocating for the marginalized, and standing up for what is right, even when it's unpopular. It means making ethical choices in our professional lives, our relationships, and our personal conduct. We must actively seek to live out God's justice in a world often marked by injustice and inequality. Thirdly, the verse underscores the generational impact of our faith. The decisions we make today will have a profound impact on the lives of our children and grandchildren. We are called to build a legacy of faith that will endure for generations to come. This requires a long-term perspective and a commitment to investing in the spiritual development of those who will come after us. Consider developing family traditions that reinforce faith values, such as reading the Bible together, praying as a family, or serving in the community. Furthermore, those in leadership positions within the church or community should take responsibility for the spiritual nurture of those under their care. This involves providing opportunities for biblical teaching, mentorship, and discipleship. Leaders should also model godly behavior and create a culture that fosters spiritual growth. Ultimately, Genesis 18:19 reminds us that our obedience to God is not merely a personal matter but has far-reaching implications for our families, our communities, and the world around us. By intentionally cultivating faith and justice, we can help bring about God's promises in our lives and in the lives of those we influence.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the example of Abraham and his commitment to raising his family in Your ways. We acknowledge our own shortcomings in this area and ask for Your forgiveness. Lord, grant us the wisdom and strength to intentionally disciple our children and those under our care. Help us to model godly behavior and create opportunities for spiritual growth. Give us a passion for justice and a desire to live righteously in all our dealings. May our lives be a testimony to Your love and grace. We pray that our children and future generations will follow in Your ways and continue the legacy of faith. Strengthen us to command our households after us in a manner pleasing to You, that they would know You intimately, seek Your will, and carry on Your truth. We ask all of this in Jesus' name. Amen.

faqs.answer: God's 'knowing' of Abraham is more than mere awareness. It's a relational intimacy, a deep understanding of Abraham's character, faith, and potential, signifying divine approval and setting the stage for his role in God's plan. This intimate knowledge is a cornerstone of their covenant relationship.
faqs.question: Q1: What does it mean for God to 'know' Abraham in Genesis 18:19?

faqs.answer: Abraham's 'command' highlights his leadership responsibility. In that patriarchal society, he was accountable for guiding his family spiritually and morally. His command was an active direction towards God's way and a protective measure against the pervasive immorality.
faqs.question: Q2: Why is it important for Abraham to 'command' his household?

faqs.answer: 'Keeping the way of the Lord' is the foundation for 'doing justice and judgment.' A life aligned with God's principles naturally leads to fair and righteous actions. Obedience to God manifests in ethical behavior towards others, reflecting God's own character.
faqs.question: Q3: How does 'keeping the way of the Lord' relate to 'doing justice and judgment'?

faqs.answer: In a modern context, 'command' can mean setting clear spiritual expectations, prioritizing family devotions, modeling godly behavior, engaging in faith-based discussions, and actively guiding children in understanding and applying biblical principles in their daily lives.
faqs.question: Q4: What are some practical ways to 'command' our household in a modern context?

faqs.answer: Genesis 18:19 is deeply rooted in covenant theology. God's promise to bless Abraham is directly tied to Abraham's commitment to raise his family in obedience. This highlights the reciprocal nature of covenant relationships: blessing hinges on faithfulness to God's commands.
